title: Signs of AI writing
description: A detailed field guide of writing and formatting patterns typical of AI-generated content, especially on Wikipedia.

common_tells: Generic praise or exaggeration of subject importance
Overuse of specific 'AI vocabulary' (e.g., pivotal, underscore, vibrant)
Section summaries with phrases like 'in summary', 'overall'
Markdown syntax or mixed formatting styles (e.g., ## headings)
Overemphasis on notability via namedropping of media coverage
Use of curly quotation marks and stylized punctuation
Superficial analyses added to factual statements
Rule of three structure (triplets of adjectives or phrases)
Malformed citations or fictional references (broken DOIs, ISBNs)
Overuse of boldface and structured lists using Markdown format
communication_clues: Starts sections with phrases like 'Let's discuss', 'Here is a template...'
Mentions formatting or user experience directly in text
Includes phrases clearly not meant for publication (e.g., 'I hope this helps')
technical_flaws: Malformed or non-existent templates and infoboxes
Incorrect wikitext syntax mixed with Markdown or HTML
Hallucinated citations or misused fields in citations

advice.use_care: Signs alone are not conclusive. Use human judgment.
false_positives: Mix of casual and formal tone
Verbose edit summaries (sometimes written by careful humans)
advice.best_practice: Do not rely solely on AI detectors; check context, writing patterns, and citation behavior.
